CHEM 1A.title: General Chemistry
CHEM 1A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 2A.
CHEM 1A.recommended_prep: Concurrent enrollment in Chemistry 1AL. High school algebra, chemistry, and physics.

CHEM 1B.title: General Chemistry
CHEM 1B.prereq_description: Chemistry 1A or 2A with a minimum grade of C-.
CHEM 1B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 2B.
CHEM 1B.recommended_prep: Chemistry 1 AL or 2AC, and concurrent enrollment in Chemistry 1BL. High school algebra, chemistry, and physics.

CHEM 1C.title: General Chemistry
CHEM 1C.prereq_description: Chemistry 1B or 2B with a minimum grade of C-.
CHEM 1C.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 2C.
CHEM 1C.description: Liquids and Intermolecular forces; properties of solutions; transition elements and coordination complexes; organic chemistry and synthetic polymers; natural polymers; nuclear chemistry.
CHEM 1C.recommended_prep: Chemistry 1BL or 2BC, and concurrent enrollment in Chemistry 1CL. High school algebra, chemistry, and physics.

CHEM 1AL.title: General Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 1AL.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 1AC or 2AC. Lab fee required.
CHEM 1AL.description: Qualitative and quantitative measurements to develop laboratory technique  and demonstrate the basic concepts of stoichiometry, chemical bonding, gas laws, chemical equilibrium, and acid-base chemistry.

CHEM 1BL.title: General Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 1BL.prereq_description: Chemistry 1A or 2A with a minimum grade of C-; Chemistry 1B or 2B (may be  taken concurrently).
CHEM 1BL.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 1BC or 2BC.
CHEM 1BL.description: Qualitative and quantitative measurements to develop laboratory technique  and demonstrate basic concepts of thermochemistry, electrochemistry,   chemical kinetics and atomic spectroscopy.

CHEM 1CL.title: General Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 1CL.prereq_description: Chemistry 1B or 2B with a minimum grade of C-; Chemistry 1C or 2C (may be  taken concurrently).
CHEM 1CL.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 1CC or 2CC.
CHEM 1CL.description: Qualitative and quantitative measurements to develop laboratory technique  and demonstrate the basic concepts of solutions, intermolecular forces,  colligative properties, and synthetic organic inorganic chemistry.

CHEM 2A.title: General Chemistry (Honors)
CHEM 2A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 1A.
CHEM 2A.description: The sequence of topics will be similar to that in Chemistry 1A. Calculus will be used as needed, at the level of the concurrent Mathematics 3A  course.
CHEM 2A.recommended_prep: Concurrent enrollment in Chemistry 2AC; high school algebra, chemistry and physics, and one quarter of calculus (may be taken concurrently).

CHEM 2B.title: General Chemistry (Honors)
CHEM 2B.prereq_description: Chemistry 2A or 1A with a minimum grade of B.
CHEM 2B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 1B.
CHEM 2B.description: Thermodynamics (first and second law), electrochemistry, chemical    kinetics, atomic and molecular structure, and chemical bonding.
CHEM 2B.recommended_prep: Chemistry 2AC or 1AL with a minimum grade of B; concurrent enrollment in Chemistry 2BC. High school algebra, chemistry, and physics, and one    quarter of calculus.

CHEM 2AC.title: General Chemistry Laboratory (Honors)
CHEM 2AC.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 1AL or 1AC.
CHEM 2AC.description: Qualitative and quantitative measurements to develop laboratory technique  and demonstate the basic concepts of stoichiometry, chemical bonding, gas  laws, chemical equilibrium, and acid-base chemistry. Students work in  small groups to develop a unique perspective on the experiment.

CHEM 2C.title: General Chemistry (Honors)
CHEM 2C.prereq_description: Chemistry 2B or 1B with a minimum grade of B.
CHEM 2C.comments: Not open for credit to students who have taken Chemistry 1C.
CHEM 2C.description: Structure and dynamics of the elements and their compounds. Aspects of   technology and environmental problems.
CHEM 2C.recommended_prep: Chemistry 2BC or 1BL with a minimum grade of B; concurrent enrollment in Chemistry 2CC. High school algebra, chemistry, and physics, and one    quarter of calculus.

CHEM 2BC.title: General Chemistry Laboratory (Honors)
CHEM 2BC.prereq_description: Chemistry 2A or 1A with a minimum grade of B; Chemistry 2AC or 1AL with a  minimum grade of B; and Chemistry 2B (may be taken concurrently).
CHEM 2BC.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter. Not open for credit to students who have taken Chemistry 1BC or 1BL.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have taken Chemistry 1BC or 1BL.
CHEM 2BC.description: Laboratory techniques. Thermochemistry, electrochemistry, chemical   kinetics, and atomic spectroscopy. Students work in small groups to  develop a unique perspective on the experiment.

CHEM 2CC.title: General Chemistry Laboratory (Honors)
CHEM 2CC.prereq_description: Chemistry 2B or 1B with a minimum grade of B; and Chemistry 2BC or 1BL
CHEM 2CC.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Spring. Not open for credit to students who have taken Chemistry 1CC or 1CL.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have taken Chemistry 1CC or 1CL.
CHEM 2CC.description: Laboratory techniques. Solutions, colligative properties, and synthetic  organic and inorganic chemistry. Students work in small groups to    develop a unique perspective on the experiment.

CHEM 6AL.title: Laboratory Methods of Organic Chemistry
CHEM 6AL.prereq_description: Chemistry 1AL or 2AC, 1BL or 2BC, and 1CL or 2CC; 109A or 109AH with a minimum grade of a C-; and Chemistry 109B or 109BH (may be taken concurrently).
CHEM 6AL.description: Distillation, crystallization, extraction, determination of physical properties, spectroscopy, and instrumental methods in organic chemistry.

CHEM 6BH.title: Laboratory Methods of Organic Chemistry (Independent Research)
CHEM 6BH.prereq_description: Chemistry 6AL and 109A or 109AH; and Chemistry 109B or 109BH (may be taken concurrently);
CHEM 6BH.description: Independent research involving distillation, crystallization, extraction, determination of physical properties, organic synthesis, and use of instrumental methods in organic chemistry.

CHEM 6BL.title: Laboratory Methods of Organic Chemistry
CHEM 6BL.prereq_description: Chemistry 6AL and 109A or 109AH with a minimum grade of C-; and Chemistry  109B or 109BH.
CHEM 6BL.description: Distillation, crystallization, extraction, determination of physical   properties, organic synthesis, instrumental methods in organic chemistry.

CHEM 6CH.title: Organic Chemistry Labs
CHEM 6CH.prereq_description: Chemistry 6BL or 6BH and 109B or 109BH; and Chemistry 109C or CHEM 109CH (may be taken concurrently); open to chemistry, biochemistry and creative studies majors only; consent of instructor.
CHEM 6CH.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring. Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 7C. Lab fee required.
CHEM 6CH.description: Independent research involving distillation, crystallization, extraction, determination of physical properties, organic synthesis, and use of instrumental methods in organic chemistry for the purposes of multistep synthesis.

CHEM 6CL.title: Organic Chemistry Labs
CHEM 6CL.prereq_description: Chemistry 6BL or 6BH and 109B or 109BH with a minimum grade of C-; and Chemistry 109C or 109CH (may be taken concurrently).
CHEM 6CL.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 7C. Lab fee required.
CHEM 6CL.description: Distillation, crystallization, extraction, determination of physical properties, organic synthesis, instrumental methods in organic chemistry.

CHEM 25.title: Introductory Chemistry
CHEM 25.prereq_description: Not open to students who have completed Natural Science 1B or Chemistry 1A or Chemistry 2A. Cannot be taken concurrently with Chemistry 1A or Chemistry 2A.
CHEM 25.comments: Designed as a preparatory course for Chemistry 1A. Intended for students with limited or no high school chemistry background, and/or students who received an SAT Math Score of 550 or below.
CHEM 25.description: Includes fundamental topics, such as matter, measurements, atomic/electronic structure, atomic theories, bonding, reactions, and stoichiometry.

CHEM 99.title: Introduction to Research
CHEM 99.comments: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 units. Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses   combined.
CHEM 99.description: Directed study, normally experimental, to be arranged with individual  faculty members. Course offers exceptional students an opportunity to  participate in a research group. Basic techniques and the operation of   instruments used in research. A few students in chemistry are quite    advanced having had extensive laboratory training in high school or    elsewhere. This course allows them the opportunity to participate in a   research group before they acquire 84 units and are then eligible for and  capable of handling 199, Independent Studies.

CHEM 102.title: Teaching Chemistry at the High School/Junior High Level
CHEM 102.comments: Open to non-majors. Upper Division course credit toward Science and Mathematics Education minor. Will not count towards the Biochemistry, Chemistry BA or Chemistry BS major requirements.
CHEM 102.description: Students will work to develop a high school/junior high curriculum unit. In addition, students will work in either a high school or junior high classroom and share their experiences through class discussions. Students will also have the opportunity to participate in one of two elementary outreach programs that are run out of the chemistry department.

CHEM 104.title: The Science and Engineering of Energy Conversion
CHEM 104.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 110A and 140A; or consent of instructor
CHEM 104.comments: Equivalent upper-division coursework in thermodynamics and kinetics from outside of the department will be considered.  Same course as CH E 141.
CHEM 104.description: Framework for understanding the energy supply issues facing society with a focus on the science,  engineering, and economic principles of the major alternatives. Emphasis is on the physical and  chemical fundamentals of energy conversion technologies.

CHEM 109A.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM 109A.prereq_description: Chemistry 1C or 2C with a minimum grade of C-; or Chemistry 1B or 2B with
CHEM 109A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 107A or 130A or 109AH.
CHEM 109A.description: Structure, reactivity and synthesis of organic molecules including nomenclature, reaction mechanisms, and stereochemistry. Topics include organometallics, polymers, carbohydrates, amino acids, proteins, nucleic acids, coenzymes and their mechanisms.

CHEM 109B.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM 109B.prereq_description: Chemistry 109A or 109AH with a minimum grade of C-.
CHEM 109B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 107B or 130B or 109BH.
CHEM 109B.description: Structure, reactivity and synthesis of organic molecules including nomenclature, reaction mechanisms, and stereochemistry. Topics include organometallics, polymers, carbohydrates, amino acides, proteins, nucleic acids, coenzymes and their mechanisms.

CHEM 109C.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM 109C.prereq_description: Chemistry 109B or 109BH with a minimum grade of C-.
CHEM 109C.comments:
Not open for credit to students who have completed CHEM 107C or CHEM 109CH or CHEM W 109C. These courses also may not be taken concurrently.
Repeat Comments: CHEM 109C is a legal repeat of CHEM W 109C (which is the online version of CHEM 109C).
CHEM 109C.description: Structure, reactivity and synthesis of organic molecules including nomenclature, reaction mechanisms, and stereochemistry. Topics include organometallics, polymers, carbohydrates, amino acides, proteins, nucleic acids, coenzymes and their mechanisms.

CHEM 109AH.title: Organic Chemistry (H)
CHEM 109AH.prereq_description: Chemistry 1B/2B or 1C/2C with a minimum grade of B.
CHEM 109AH.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 109A or   130A.
CHEM 109AH.description: Structure, nomenclature, stereochemistry, and reactivity of organic  molecules.  Suitable for undergraduates requiring strong understanding of organic chemistry and possessing strong background in science, such as honors students, majors in chemistry, biochemistry-chem, chemical   engineering, etc.  This course cannot be repeated.

CHEM 109BH.title: Organic Chemistry (H)
CHEM 109BH.prereq_description: Chemistry 109A with a minimum grade of B+ or Chemistry 109AH with a
CHEM 109BH.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 109B or   130B.
CHEM 109BH.description: Structure, nomenclature, stereochemistry, and reactivity of organic  molecules. Suitable for undergraduates requiring strong understanding of organic chemistry and possessing  strong background in science, such as  honors students, majors in chemistry, biochemistry-chem, chemical    engineering, etc.  This course cannot be repeated.

CHEM 109CH.title: Organic Chemistry (H)
CHEM 109CH.prereq_description: Chemistry 109B with a minimum grade of B+ or Chemistry 109BH with a
CHEM 109CH.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 109C or   130C.
CHEM 109CH.description: Structure, reactivity, mechanisms, synthesis, nomenclature, and    spectroscopic identification of the principal classes of organic   compounds as well as organometallics, amino acids, proteins, and   carbohydrates. This course is intended for chemistry majors and others requiring a strong basis in organic chemistry.

CHEM 110.title: Introduction to the Chemical Applications of Group Theory
CHEM 110.prereq_description: Chem 1A, 1B, or 2A, 2B.  Concurrent enrollment in Chem 1C or 2C.
CHEM 110.comments: Designed for majors. Same course as Chem CS 110. Not open for credit to students who have completed Chem CS 110.  Any major outside the Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry will need instructor approval.
CHEM 110.description: The mathematics of group theory is introduced.  Point groups and symmetryoperations will be applied toward the normal coordinate analysis of molecular vibrations and the construction of molecular orbitals from symmetry adapted linear combinations of atomic orbitals.

CHEM 110L.title: Introductory Biochemistry Laboratory
CHEM 110L.prereq_description: Chemistry 142A or Chemistry W 142A (may be taken concurrently).
CHEM 110L.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall. Lab fee required.
CHEM 110L.description: Gives students hands-on experience with modern methods of separation,  identification, and study of biomolecules and macromolecular structures. Focus is on techniques but the course also gives an introduction to  computer-based bioinformatics tools.
CHEM 110L.recommended_prep: Chemistry 6AL-BL; and Chemistry 107A-B-C or 109A or 109AH-109B or    109BH-109C or 109CH.

CHEM 111.title: Chemical Kinetics
CHEM 111.description: The laws and theories governing rates of chemical reactions and reaction mechanisms. Empirical treatment of reaction rates, treatment of data,  gas-phase reactions, reactions in solution, catalysis, complex reactions,  chain reactions. Collision theory and potential energy surfaces.

CHEM 112A.title: Biophysical Chemistry
CHEM 112A.prereq_description: Chemistry 1C or 2C; and, Mathematics 2A-B or 3A-B, 4A or 3C, and 6A or 5A; and,
CHEM 112A.description: Laws of thermodynamics, chemical equilibria and ligand binding, phase equilibria, electrochemistry, nonelectrolyte solutions, applications to biochemical problems.

CHEM 112B.title: Biophysical Chemistry
CHEM 112B.prereq_description: Chemistry 112A; Chemistry 142A or Chemistry W 142A or MCDB 108A;
CHEM 112B.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter. Not open to students who have completed Chemistry 113B
Repeat Comments: Illegal Repeat of Chemistry 113B.
CHEM 112B.description: Forces influencing macromolecular conformation, microscopy and diffraction methods, quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics.

CHEM 112C.title: Biophysical Chemistry
CHEM 112C.prereq_description: Chemistry 112B; Chemistry 142B or MCDB 108B; Chemistry 142C or MCDB 108C
CHEM 112C.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Spring. Not open to students who have completed Chemistry 113C.
Repeat Comments: Illegal Repeat of Chemistry 113C.
CHEM 112C.description: Biological spectroscopy, nuclear magnetic resonance, mass transport    dynamics in solution, chemical and biochemical kinetics.

CHEM 112L.title: Biophysical and Bioanalytical Laboratory
CHEM 112L.prereq_description: Chemistry 125L and Chemistry 142C (may be taken concurrently).
CHEM 112L.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring. Lab fee required.
CHEM 112L.description: Application of modern biophysical and bioanalytical techniques to study the structure, function, and properties of biomolecules. Fluorescence spectroscopy, mass spectroscopy, FTIR, 2D-NMR, diffraction techniques, circular dichroism.

CHEM 113A.title: Physical Chemistry
CHEM 113A.prereq_description: Chemistry 1C or 2C; and, Mathematics 2A-B or 3A-B, 4A or 3C, and 6A or 5A; and,
CHEM 113A.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Fall. Not open to students who have completed Chemistry 112A.
Repeat Comments: Illegal Repeat of CHEM 112A.
CHEM 113A.description: Chemical thermodynamics: laws of thermodynamics, phase equilibria, chemical equilibria, equations of state.

CHEM 113B.title: Physical Chemistry
CHEM 113B.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter. Not open to students who have completed  Chemistry 112B.
CHEM 113B.description: Quantum theory and spectroscopy: introduction to quantum mechanics;    symmetry, molecular structure, and spectroscopy.
CHEM 113B.recommended_prep: Chemistry 150 and 116AL (may be taken concurrently), Math 4B.

CHEM 113C.title: Physical Chemistry
CHEM 113C.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Spring. Not open to students who have completed Chemistry 112C.
Repeat Comments: Illegal Repeat of CHEM 112C.
CHEM 113C.description: Kinetic theory of gases, chemical kinetics, statistical mechanics,   photochemistry.

CHEM 113AL.title: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 113AL.description: Lecture: instrumental techniques, data analysis, error analysis,     instruction in Mathematica-R. Laboratory: Mathematica-R, a symbolic    programming language, is taught in the computer laboratory.

CHEM 115A.title: Fundamentals of Quantum Chemistry
CHEM 115A.description: Introduction to quantum mechanics-postulatory approach; particle in box, on ring, harmonic oscillator; linear operator theory, matrix algebra; hydrogen atom; perturbation theory, variation theory; applications.

CHEM 115B.title: Fundamentals of Quantum Chemistry
CHEM 115B.description: Molecular orbital theory and valence bond theory; Huckel theory (secular eqn.) applications to conjugated systems, electronic spectra, and term symbols; introduction to infrared, Raman, and microwave spectroscopy.

CHEM 115C.title: Fundamentals of Quantum Chemistry
CHEM 115C.description: Introduction to NMR, EPR, group theory; and applications.

CHEM 116AL.title: Quantitative Analytical and Physical Methods Laboratory
CHEM 116AL.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter. Lab fee required.
CHEM 116AL.description: Principles of analytical chemistry including spectroscopy, classical   techniques and separation processes. Quantitative analysis of unknowns.  Introduction to instrumental analysis.

CHEM 116BL.title: Advanced Physical Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 116BL.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring. Lab fee required.
CHEM 116BL.description: Experiments in thermodynamics, spectroscopy, and electrochemistry.   Synthesis and study of inorganic complexes. Instrumental techniques such as NMR, fluorescence, Raman and laser flash photolysis are explored. Methods of data and error analysis.

CHEM 116CL.title: Inorganic Synthesis and Physical Characterization Laboratory
CHEM 116CL.prereq_description: Chemistry 113C and 116BL; Chemistry 173A (may be taken concurrently).
CHEM 116CL.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall. Lab fee required.
CHEM 116CL.description: Synthesis of inorganic and organometallic complexes including techniques for air-sensitive materials. Instrumental characterization and study of  synthesized compounds in a research-like setting.

CHEM 117A.title: Statistical Mechanics
CHEM 117A.description: Fundamentals of statistical thermodynamics, partition functions for ideal  gases and crystals, quantum statistics, calculations of thermodynamic  properties.

CHEM 118.title: Photochemistry and Radiation Chemistry
CHEM 118.description: Interaction of light and matter, reaction paths from electronically    excited molecules, flash photolysis, high energy radiation.

CHEM 123.title: Fundamentals of Environmental Chemistry
CHEM 123.description: Study of Earth's biogeochemical cycles with respect to carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur. Introduction to the science of climate change, including   effects of global warming on terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.     Environmental impacts of fossil fuel and biofuel technologies.     Chemistry of the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and lithosphere, with emphasis on ozone depletion, photochemical smog, acid rain, global ocean    acidification, soil and groundwater contamination, and environmental costs of industrialized agriculture.

CHEM 124.title: Organic Spectroscopic Analysis
CHEM 124.description: Structure determination of complex organic molecules. Topics covered   include NMR, IR, UV, and mass spectrometry.

CHEM 125L.title: Laboratory Techniques in Biochemistry
CHEM 125L.prereq_description: Chemistry 110L; and Chemistry 142A or Chemistry W 142A; and Chemistry
CHEM 125L.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter. Lab fee required.
CHEM 125L.description: Application of molecular biology techniques to perform mutagenesis and cloning; restriction endonucleases, PCR, plasmid purification and DNA  analysis. Protein purification and analysis methods: expression of   proteins in bacterial systems.
CHEM 125L.recommended_prep: Chemistry 109A or 109AH-109B or 109BH-109C or 109CH; and Chemistry   6AL-BL.

CHEM 126.title: Computation Chemistry and Molecular Modeling
CHEM 126.description: Introduction to computational chemistry and molecular modeling.    Application of molecular mechanics, quantum mechanics and computer   graphical interfaces to problems in chemistry, biochemistry, drug design and pharmacology.

CHEM 127.title: Structure and Reactivity in Organic Chemistry
CHEM 127.prereq_description: Chemistry 107A-B-C or 109A-B-C with a C or better.
CHEM 127.description: Electronic structure, resonance, acid/base chemistry, thermodynamics,  kinetics, transition state theory, and isotope effects.

CHEM 128.title: Organic Reaction Mechanisms
CHEM 128.description: Mechanisms of thermal, photochemical, organometallic, electrochemical asymmetric or other processes in organic chemistry.

CHEM 129.title: Synthetic Organic Reactions
CHEM 129.description: A survey of reactions of organic substances with emphasis on those with  practical synthetic utility, including discussion of mechanism, scope and  limitations, and steriochemical issues.

CHEM W 109C.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM W 109C.prereq_description: Chemistry 109B or 109BH with a minimum grade of C-.
CHEM W 109C.comments:
This is an online version of the regular CHEM 109C. Not open for credit to students who have completed CHEM 107C or CHEM 109CH or CHEM 109C. These courses also may not be taken concurrently.
Repeat Comments: CHEM W 109C is a legal repeat of CHEM 109C.
CHEM W 109C.description: Structure, reactivity and synthesis of organic molecules including nomenclature, reaction mechanisms, and stereochemistry. Topics include organometallics, polymers, carbohydrates, amino acides, proteins, nucleic acids, coenzymes and their mechanisms.

CHEM 130A.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM 130A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 107A.
CHEM 130A.description: Structure, reactivity, mechanisms, synthesis, nomenclature, and spectroscopic identification of the principle classes of organic compounds as well as organometallics, amino acids, proteins, and carbohydrates. This course is intended for chemistry majors and others requiring a strong basis in organic chemistry.

CHEM 130B.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM 130B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 107B.
CHEM 130B.description: Structure, reactivity, mechanisms, synthesis, nomenclature, and spectroscopic identification of the principal classes of organic compounds as well as organometallics, amino acids, proteins, and carbohydrates. This course is intended for chemistry majors and others requiring a strong basis in organic chemistry (see majors in biochemistry-molecular biology, chemical engineering, pharmacology, physiology, and cell biology).

CHEM 130C.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM 130C.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 108.
CHEM 130C.description: Structure, reactivity, mechanisms, synthesis, nomenclature, and spectroscopic identification of the principal classes of organic compounds as well as organometallics, amino acids, proteins, and carbohydrates. This course is intended for chemistry majors and others requiring a strong basis in organic chemistry.

CHEM 132.title: Organometallics in Organic Synthesis
CHEM 132.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
CHEM 132.description: Synthetic methods and applications to natural products total syntheses involving transition metals.

CHEM 133.title: Advanced Synthetic Chemistry
CHEM 133.prereq_description: Chemistry 109A-B-C; upper-division standing; open to chemistry and
CHEM 133.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
CHEM 133.description: A comprehensive discussion of modern synthetic organic methods,    including the applications of addition, condensation, substitution,  and rearrangement reactions for building complicated molecules from  scratch.
CHEM 133.recommended_prep: Taken or concurrently enrolled in Chem 129.

CHEM 134.title: Chemical Synthesis of Biological Molecules
CHEM 134.description: The synthesis, manipulation, and modification of biological molecules  including peptides, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and other metabolites  are essential to advances in biomedicine.  This course surveys chemical  methods for the production of these molecules and their application to   biological problems.

CHEM 141.title: Epigenetics: Biology, Mechanisms and Therapies
CHEM 141.prereq_description: Chemistry W142A or 142A, 142B-C; or, MCDB 108A-B-C; upper-division
CHEM 141.description: Covers epigenetic processes and molecular mechanisms in bacteria, fungi, plants, mammals, imprinting, gene regulation, repeat-induced point mutation (RIP), X-  chromosome inactivation, epigenetic mechanisms including DNA methylation, histone modification, chromatin remodeling, RNA silencing, and epigentically based therapeutics and pharmaco-epigenetics.

CHEM 142A.title: Biochemistry
CHEM 142A.prereq_description: Chemistry 107A-B-C or 109A or 109AH-109B or 109BH-109C or 109CH or W 109C
CHEM 142A.description: Macromolecules of biological importance. A survey of the physical and chemical properties of proteins, nucleic acids, and carbohydrates. Methods of preparation, chemical synthesis, degradation, and characterization of biomolecules.

CHEM 142B.title: Biochemistry
CHEM 142B.description: Chemical aspects of intermediary metabolism. The chemistry and elementary dynamic properties of enzymes; study of enzyme active sites; characterization of metabolic pathways and methods of examining cellular regulation.

CHEM 142C.title: Biochemistry
CHEM 142C.description: Macromolecular biosynthesis and specialized cellular processes. A survey of nucleic acid and protein biosynthesis, characterization of lipids and membranes; function of membranes in transport, energy transduction, and  cellular control; mechanisms of muscle contraction and cell motility.

CHEM 142AH.title: Biochemistry-Honors Discussion
CHEM 142AH.description: Discussion sections using science articles to convey how science gets done and its limitations. Students learn how to read science papers,  the publication process, resources for finding papers and how to dissect them into experiments and conclusions. Students attend research seminars and group meetings involving presentations by Chemistry & Biochemistry graduate students.

CHEM 142BH.title: Biochemistry-Honors Discussion
CHEM 142BH.description: Discussion sections using science articles to convey how science gets done and its limitations. Students learn how to read science papers,  the publication process, resources for finding papers and how to dissect them into experiments and conclusions. Students will attend research   seminars and group meetings involving presentations by Chemistry &   Biochemistry graduate students.

CHEM 142CH.title: Biochemistry-Honors Discussion
CHEM 142CH.description: Discussion sections using science articles to convey how science gets done and its limitations. Students learn how to read science papers,  the publication process, resources for finding papers and how to dissect them into experiments and conclusions. Students will attend research   seminars and group meetings involving presentations by Chemistry &   Biochemistry graduate students.

CHEM 143.title: The RNA World
CHEM 143.description: Introduction to RNA structure and thermodynamics. Biological roles of RNA in contemporary organisms. Implications for the origins of life.

CHEM 145.title: Computational Biochemistry
CHEM 145.prereq_description: Chemistry 113A-B or Chemistry 112A-B; and, Chemistry 142A or Chem W142A
CHEM 145.comments: Offered concurrently with Chemistry 245 and BMB 245.
CHEM 145.description: Introduction to molecular modeling and molecular dynamics. Discussion of practical considerations of energy minimization, solvent modeling, structure-based drug design. Practical computer graphics experience.

CHEM 146.title: Membrane Biochemistry
CHEM 146.prereq_description: Chem 142A or Chem W142A or MCDB 108A; Chemistry 142B or MCDB 108B (may be
CHEM 146.description: Introduction to the structures and roles of lipids and their phase behavior, liposomes, membrane proteins and kinetics, protein sorting, and signal transduction.

CHEM 147.title: Astrobiology and the Origins of Life
CHEM 147.prereq_description: Chemistry 142A or Chem W142A or MCDB 108A.
CHEM 147.description: Discusses the origins and evolution of the solar system and the earth, the origins and evolution of life on earth, and the possibilities for life elsewhere in the cosmos,  all from the perspective of contemporary, terrain biochemistry.

CHEM 148.title: Introduction to Nucleic Acid Nanotechnology and Synthetic Biology
CHEM 148.prereq_description: Chemistry 142A or Chemistry W 142A, and Chemistry 142B; or MCDB 108A or MCDB W 108A and MCDB 108B
CHEM 148.description: This integrative, interdisciplinary course introduces Nucleic Acid Nanotechnology and Synthetic Biology from molecular, biochemical, biophysical and evolutionary perspectives. Recent developments aiming at engineering new biomaterials, therapeutics, nano-machines, nano-robots, alternative genetic and regulatory systems and new cellular organisms will be presented.

CHEM 149.title: How Science Works
CHEM 149.comments: Open to non-majors. This course requires attendance/participation in a lab once (three to four hours) during three different weeks of the quarter.
CHEM 149.description: Combined lab and discussion course on how science works. Includes three  labs on student-generated questions. Discussions include the analysis of research papers, science controversies, how science defines new areas of ?ignorance,? and the observation of research group meetings.

CHEM 150.title: Analytical Chemistry
CHEM 150.description: Principles of analytical chemistry including classical techniques,   spectrophotochemistry, electroanalytical techniques, and separation    processes.

CHEM 151.title: Post-translational Protein Processing
CHEM 151.prereq_description: MCDB 108A or Chemistry 142A with a grade of C or better.
CHEM 151.description: Structure/function relationships in interesting macromolecules isolated from marine organisms. Focus is on well-characterized pathways from horseshoe crabs, abolones, mussels, and fish as well as others.

CHEM 153.title: Advanced Analytical Techniques
CHEM 153.description: Principles of analytical methodology, as in spectroscopy, electroanalysis, and chromatography. Applications to environmental problems, forensic and clinical analysis, and industry. Analysis of solids and surfaces.

CHEM 154A.title: Magnetic Resonance in Biological Systems
CHEM 154A.description: A discussion of the theory and practice of magnetic resonance methods used in studies of proteins, nucleic acids, and polysaccharides.

CHEM 154B.title: Magnetic Resonance in Biological Systems
CHEM 154B.prereq_description: Chemistry 113A-B or Chemistry 112A-B; and, Chemistry 112C or 113C (may be  taken
CHEM 154B.description: A discussion of the theory and practice of magnetic resonance methods used in studies of proteins, nucleic acids, and polysaccharides.

CHEM 161.title: Enzyme Mechanisms
CHEM 161.description: Chemistry, structure and function of enzymes; theory, experimental design, and data analysis. Enzyme models and non-classical enzymes.

CHEM 162A.title: Drug Design
CHEM 162A.description: Sources for new drugs. Biochemistry of diseases. Target validation techniques. Mechanism of action of enzymes and receptors. Enzyme inhibition and receptor binding studies. Structure based drug design: conformational analysis, docking and binding affinity calculations. Course also teaches proposal writing skills.

CHEM 162B.title: Drug Design
CHEM 162B.description: Medical chemistry for lead optimization, combinatorial synthesis, quantitative structure-activity relationships, pharmocokinetics, drug metabolism and toxicity, pharmacogenomics. Drugs that interact with DNA and protein drugs. Clinical trials, intellectual property in drug design. Students develop their own drug design project.

CHEM W 142A.title: Biochemistry
CHEM W 142A.prereq_description: Chemistry 107A-B-C or 109A or 109AH-109B or 109BH-109C or 109CH or W 109C
CHEM W 142A.description: Macromolecules of biological importance. A survey of the physical and chemical properties of proteins, nucleic acids, and carbohydrates. Methods of preparation, chemical synthesis, degradation, and characterization of biomolecules.

CHEM 163.title: Arrow Pushing in Organic Chemistry
CHEM 163.prereq_description: Chemistry 109A-B-C; upper-division standing; open to chemistry and
CHEM 163.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
CHEM 163.description: Covers the arrow pushing formalism and addresses organic reactions from this perspective.
CHEM 163.recommended_prep: Taken or concurrently enrolled in one of the following; Chemistry 127, 128, 129, or 133.

CHEM 171.title: Bioinorganic Chemistry
CHEM 171.description: Selected topics in bioinorganic chemistry, and metallo-biochemistry.   Discussions of metalloproteins and corresponding model compound    investigations. Emphasis will be on reaction mechanisms and spectroscopy or properties of metal sites.

CHEM 173A.title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 173A.comments: Concurrently offered with Chemistry 268A. Quarters usually offered:    Summer, Fall.
CHEM 173A.description: Electronic structure of atoms and molecules. Models for bonding in   molecules of nontransition and transition elements. Applications of  symmetry to bonding, electronic and vibrational spectroscopy.    Stereochemistry of transition metal complexes and introduction to  organometallics.

CHEM 173B.title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 173B.comments: Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with Chemistry 268B. Quarters  usually offered: Winter.
CHEM 173B.description: Structures of ordered crystalline solids, X-Ray crystallography.   Introduction to solid state chemistry, inorganic materials and chemical  catalysis. Bioinorganic chemistry.

CHEM 175.title: Physical-Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 175.description: Bonding theory, thermodynamics, and structure of inorganic compounds. Applications of physical techniques to the study of inorganic (and organometallic) reactions and their mechanisms.

CHEM 176.title: Photochemical and Photophysical Properties of Inorganic and Organometallic Compounds and Materials
CHEM 176.description: Discussion of the mechanisms of fundamental physical and chemical events which follow absorption of light by inorganic and organometallic     chromophores. Consideration of homogeneous and heterogeneous systems as  well as the design and operation of photo-optical and photoelectrical  devices.

CHEM 181.title: Protein Crystallography
CHEM 181.description: Introduction to diffraction techniques. Protein crystal growth and   morphology. Data collection and reduction strategies. Approaches for   solving the phase problem. Crystallographic refinement, including    molecular dynamics. Interpretation of crystal structures.

CHEM 183.title: Introduction to Teaching in Chemistry
CHEM 183.prereq_description: Upper-division standing, a chemistry grade point average of 3.5 or above and consent of instructor.
CHEM 183.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 5 units. May not be applied toward the major.
CHEM 183.description: Students will assist the teaching assistant in teaching a lab course in which the student previously received a grade of A- or better. Activities will be determined in consultation with the instructor and include instruction of 1 or 2 lab sections per week. Undergraduates enrolled in Chem 183 are learning assistants (LAs) in the general chemistry laboratory. LAs teach and mentor first-year university students. LAs assist students with experiments, lab technique, data analysis, calculations, learning chemistry concepts, and problem solving.  As the LAs learn STEM education pedagogy, they can practice what they learn as LAs in the chemistry lab.

CHEM 184.title: Chemical Literature
CHEM 184.description: Lectures and exercises on the literature and other information resources of use in chemistry.

CHEM 186.title: Organometallic Chemistry: Structure, Bonding, and Applications
CHEM 186.description: Synthesis, structure, and reactivity of organometallic complexes, with an emphasis on bonding and electronic structure. Homogeneous catalysis and small molecule activation, especially in the context of the energy conversion and storage, will also be discussed.

CHEM 192.title: Honors Research Seminar
CHEM 192.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor and department.
CHEM 192.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.5 GPA. No units may be applied to the   major. An application must be completed and submitted to the undergrad   advisor early in the first quarter of the senior year. Students    successfully completing the program are eligible to graduate with    Distinction in the Major.
CHEM 192.description: Independent research project carried out under the supervision of faculty  member. Goal is to write an original, publishable, research paper. The   project can be on a topic of the student's choice, or it can be an   extension of an ongoing research project under the direction of a faculty  member in the department.

CHEM 193.title: Internship in Chemistry
CHEM 193.prereq_description: Chem 1AL, 1BL, 1CL, and consent of Chem instructor.
CHEM 193.comments: Designed for majors. Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA. No units may be applied to the major. An application must be completed and submitted to the department chair.
CHEM 193.description: Opportunity to obtain practical non paid chemistry-related research and work experience by working under faculty and/or staff direction as an intern.

CHEM 196.title: Special Topics
CHEM 196.comments: Chem 196 may apply to major requirements by petition only.
CHEM 196.description: Special topics and courses as a means of meeting special curriculum  needs.

CHEM 198.title: Research in Chemical Education
CHEM 198.prereq_description: Upper-division standing in a physical science, life science, or
CHEM 198.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
CHEM 198.description: Coursework shall consist of research in chemical education supervised by a faculty member. This course is not intended for internship credit.

CHEM 199.title: Independent Studies
CHEM 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing in the major; completion of two upper division
CHEM 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and  are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all     98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
CHEM 199.description: Coursework shall consist of academic research supervised by a faculty  member. This course is not intended for internship credit.

CHEM 204.title: Advanced Science and Engineering of Energy Conversion
CHEM 204.description: The course provides a framework for understanding the energy supply issues facing society with a focus on the science, engineering, and economic principles of the major alternatives. Emphasis will be on the physical and chemical fundamentals of energy conversion technologies.

CHEM 217A.title: Statistical Mechanics
CHEM 217A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 117A.
CHEM 217A.description: Fundamentals of statistical thermodynamics, partition functions for ideal  gases and crystals, quantum statistics, calculations of thermodynamic  properties.

CHEM 217B.title: Statistical Mechanics
CHEM 217B.description: Fundamentals of non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, kinetic theory of gases, Boltzmann equation, correlation functions, linear response theory, fluctuation-dissipation theorem, Langevin and Fokker-  Planck equations.

CHEM 217C.title: Statistical Mechanics
CHEM 217C.description: Selected topics in advanced statistical mechanics. Phase transitions and the renormalization group. Theory of rate processes.

CHEM 218.title: Photochemistry and Radiation Chemistry
CHEM 218.prereq_description: Open only by consent of the chemistry graduate advisor.
CHEM 218.description: Interaction of light and matter, reaction paths from electonically excited molecules, flash photolysis, high energy radiation.

CHEM 219.title: Selected Topics in Physical Chemistry
CHEM 219.comments: Course may be repeated with a different topic (18 units maximum).
CHEM 219.description: Selected topics: orbital symmetry rules for chemical reactions (Pearson);  classical theory of light, radiation, and spectroscopy (Metiu); nonlinear  optics and nonlinear spectroscopy (Metiu).

CHEM 222A.title: Fundamentals of Quantum Chemistry
CHEM 222A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 115A-B-C.
CHEM 222A.description: Introduction to quantum mechanics-postulatory approach; particle in box, on ring, harmonic oscillator; lineral operator theory, matrix algebra; hydrogen atom; perturbation theory, variation theory; applications.

CHEM 222B.title: Fundamentals of Quantum Chemistry
CHEM 222B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 115A-B-C.
CHEM 222B.description: Molecular Orbital theory and Valence Bond theory (Secular Equ.) applications to conjugated systems, electronic spectra, and term symbols; introduction to infrared, raman, and microwave spectroscopy.

CHEM 222C.title: Fundamentals of Quantum Chemistry
CHEM 222C.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 115A-B-C.
CHEM 222C.description: Introduction to NMR, EPR, group theory; applications.

CHEM 223.title: Current Events in Organic Chemistry
CHEM 223.description: Faculty and students present and critically discuss current chemical   literature.

CHEM 224.title: Organic Spectroscopic Analysis
CHEM 224.description: Structure determination of complex organic molecules. Topics include NMR,  IR, UV, and mass spectrometry.

CHEM 225.title: Instrumental Methods in Physical Chemistry
CHEM 225.comments: May be repeated with different topics to a maximum of nine units. Advanced undergraduates may enroll by petition to their college office.
CHEM 225.description: Fundamentals of basic measurements and advanced research instrumentation are taught. Emphasis is on both practical and conceptual understanding of  the methods, suitable for experimental design. Signal electronics, vacuum  techniques, molecularbeams, lasers, and optics.

CHEM 226.title: Computational Chemistry
CHEM 226.description: Introduction to computational chemistry and molecular modeling.    Applications of molecular mechanics, quantum mechanics, and computer   graphical interfaces to problems in chemistry, biochemistry, drug design,  and pharmacology.

CHEM 227.title: Structure and Reactivity in Organic Chemistry
CHEM 227.description: Electronic structure, resonance, acid/base chemistry, thermodynamics,  kinetics, transition state theory, and isotope effects.

CHEM 228.title: Organic Reaction Mechanisms
CHEM 228.description: Mechanisms of thermal, photochemical, organometallic, electrochemical,   asymmetric or other processes in organic chemistry.

CHEM 229.title: Synthetic Organic Reactions
CHEM 229.description: A survey of reactions of organic substances with emphasis on those with  practical synthetic utility, including discussion of mechanism, scope and  limitations, and stereochemical issues.

CHEM 232.title: Organometallics in Organic Synthesis
CHEM 232.comments: Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with 132. Quarters usually   offered: Spring.
CHEM 232.description: Synthetic methods and applications to natural products total syntheses involving transition metals.

CHEM 233.title: Advanced Synthetic Chemistry
CHEM 233.description: A comprehensive discussion of modern synthetic organic methods, including  the applications of addition, condensation, substitution, and      rearrangement reactions.

CHEM 234.title: Chemical Synthesis of Biological Molecules
CHEM 234.prereq_description: Chemistry 229; graduate standing; consent of instructor.
CHEM 234.comments: Concurrently offered with CHEM 134. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
CHEM 234.description: The synthesis, manipulation, and modification of biological molecules  including peptides, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and other metabolites  are essential to advances in biomedicine. This course surveys chemical   methods for the production of these molecules and their application to   biological problems.

CHEM 239AAZZ.title: Selected Topics in Organic Chemistry
CHEM 239AAZZ.comments: May be repeated provided topics are different. Only 18 units of total credit may apply to the major.
CHEM 239AAZZ.description: Selected topics from organic chemistry the contents of this course will vary.

CHEM 240.title: Chemistry of Organic Semiconductors
CHEM 240.description: Synthesis, electronic structure, photophysics and applications of organic  semiconductors.  Emphasis will be placed on materials based on conjugated  polymers.  Applications of interest include solar cell devices,    biosensors, and light emitting diodes.

CHEM 241.title: Epigenetics: Biology, Mechanisms and Therapies
CHEM 241.prereq_description: Chemistry W142A or 142A, 142B-C; or, MCDB 108A-B-C; graduate standing.
CHEM 241.description: Covers epigenetic processes and molecular mechanisms in bacteria, fungi, plants, mammals, imprinting, gene regulation, repeat-induced point mutation (RIP), X-  chromosome inactivation, epigenetic mechanisms including DNA methylation, histone modification, chromatin remodeling, RNA silencing, and epigentically based therapeutics and pharmaco-epigenetics.

CHEM 242A.title: Chemical Aspects of Biological Systems
CHEM 242A.prereq_description: Open only by consent of the chemistry graduate advisor.
CHEM 242A.description: Macromolecules of biological importance. A survey of the physical and  chemical properties of proteins, nucleic acids, and carbohydrates. Methods of preparation, chemical synthesis, degradation, and characterization of biomolecules.

CHEM 242B.title: Chemical Aspects of Biological Systems
CHEM 242B.prereq_description: Open only by consent of the chemistry graduate advisor.
CHEM 242B.description: Chemical aspects of intermediary metabolism. The chemistry and elementary  dynamic properties of enzymes; study of enzyme active sites;     characterization of metabolic pathways and methods of examining cellular regulation.

CHEM 242C.title: Chemical Aspects of Biological Systems
CHEM 242C.prereq_description: Open only by consent of the chemistry graduate advisor.
CHEM 242C.description: Macromolecular biosynthesis and specialized cellular processes. A survey of nucleic acid and protein biosynthesis, characterization of lipids and membranes; function of membranes in transport, energy transduction, and  cellular control; mechanisms of muscle contraction and cell motility;  neurochemistry.

CHEM 243.title: The RNA World
CHEM 243.description: Introduction to RNA structure and thermodynamics. Biological roles of RNA in contemporary organisms. Implications for the origins of life.

CHEM 244.title: Informational Macro- and Supra-Molecules
CHEM 244.description: Selected topics at the interface of chemistry and biology; informational molecular coding, molecular machines, self-assembling and self-replicating molecular systems, evolution and selection of molecules with binding and catalytic properties, biopolymer-based materials, special emphasis on  cutting-edge technologies.

CHEM 245.title: Computational Biochemistry
CHEM 245.description: Introduction to molecular modeling and molecular dynamics. Discussion of practical considerations of energy minimization, solvent modeling, structure-based drug design. Practical computer graphics experience.

CHEM 246.title: Membrane Biochemistry
CHEM 246.description: Introduction to the structures and roles of lipids an their behavior, liposomes, membrane proteins and kinetics, protein sorting, and signal transduction.

CHEM 248.title: Reaction Rate Theory
CHEM 248.description: Advanced theoretical and computational methods for the analysis of   reaction kinetics and mechanisms. Topics include transition state theory,  Kramers' theory, tunneling effects, transition state search algorithms,  transition path sampling, kinetic Monte Carlo, reaction coordinate and   degree-of-rate-control analyses.

CHEM 251.title: Post-Translational Protein Processing
CHEM 251.prereq_description: MCDB 108A or MCDB 218A or Chemistry 142A or equivalent.
CHEM 251.description: Structure/function relationships in interesting macromolecules isolated  from marine organisms. Focus is on well-characterized pathways from    horseshoe crabs, abalones, mussels, and fish as well as others.

CHEM 254A.title: Magnetic Resonance in Biological Systems
CHEM 254A.description: A discussion of the theory and practice of magnetic resonance methods used in studies of proteins, nucleic acids, and polysaccharides.

CHEM 254B.title: Magnetic Resonance Techniques in Biological Systems
CHEM 254B.description: A discussion of the theory and practice of magnetic resonance methods  currently used in studies of proteins, nucleic acids, and polysaccharides  both individually and in complex structures such as membranes. nmr and epr techniques will be included but the emphasis will be on high-resolution 1H and 13C spectroscopy.

CHEM 257.title: Strategy in Organic Synthesis and Methodology
CHEM 257.description: The design, development, presentation, and organization of new concepts for organic synthesis and methodologies is an essential skill for graduate students. Course  focuses on advances in these areas and developing skills for writing and presenting research proposals.
CHEM 257.recommended_prep: Primarily intended for graduate students in the organic division.

CHEM 259.title: Selected Topics in Biological Chemistry
CHEM 259.comments: Same course as BMSE 259. Course may be repeated with a different topic (18 units maximum).
CHEM 259.description: Selected topics from bio-organic, biophysical, or biological chemistry.  Thecontent of this course will vary.

CHEM 261.title: Enzyme Mechanisms
CHEM 261.description: Chemistry, structure, and function of enzymes; theory, experimental    design,and data analysis. Enzyme models and non-classical enzymes.

CHEM 262A.title: Drug Design
CHEM 262A.description: Sources for new drugs. Biochemistry of diseases. Target validation   techniques. Mechanism of action of enzymes and receptors. Enzyme     inhibition and receptor binding studies. Structure base drug design:   conformational analysis, docking and binding affinity calculations. Course also teaches proposal writing skills.

CHEM 262B.title: Drug Design
CHEM 262B.description: Medicinal chemistry for lead optimization, combinatorial synthesis,    quantitative structure-activity relationships, pharmacokinetics, drug  metabolism and toxicity, pharmacogenomics. Drugs that interact with DNA  and Protein drugs. Clinical trials, intellectual property in drug design.  Students develop their own drug design project.

CHEM 263.title: Arrow Pushing in Organic Chemistry
CHEM 263.description: Covers the arrow pushing fomulasism and addresses molecular rearrangements and other organic reactions from this perspective.
CHEM 263.recommended_prep: a previous or current course in one of the following; Chemistry 227, 228, 229 or 233.

CHEM 264.title: Advanced Catalysis
CHEM 264.description: Theories of reaction rates. Heterogeneous and homogenous catalysis, including physical structure and characterization of catalysts. Catalyst poisoning.

CHEM 265.title: Industrial Methods for Polymer Synthesis
CHEM 265.description: Covers in detail the methods of polymer preparation currently practiced in industry. Special coverage of structure/property relationships in    polymers, the design and mechanism of action of successful catalysts, and  the transformation of basic polymerization reactions into large-scale  processes.

CHEM 266.title: Photophysics and Device Science of Organic Materials
CHEM 266.description: Examination of what happens when organic molecules absorb a photon or when they are incorporated within an optoelectric device. Specific subjects   include phtoexcitation and relaxation processes, energy transfer,    flourescence depolarization, the design of flourescence-based biosensors,  organic light emitting diodes and field effect transistors.

CHEM 268A.title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 268A.prereq_description: Consent of the chemistry graduate advisor.
CHEM 268A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 173A, or  272A.
CHEM 268A.description: Electronic structure of atoms and molecules. Models for bonding in   molecules of nontransition and transition elements. Applications of    symmetry to bonding, electronic and vibrational spectroscopy.      Stereochemistry of transition metal complexes and introduction to organo-  metallics.

CHEM 268B.title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 268B.prereq_description: Consent of the chemistry graduate advisor.
CHEM 268B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemistry 173B or 272B.
CHEM 268B.description: Structures of ordered crystalline solids, x-ray crystallography.     Introduction to solid state chemistry, inorganic materials and chemical  catalysis. Bioinorganic chemistry.

CHEM 270.title: Graduate Seminar in Inorganic/Analytical Chemistry
CHEM 270.description: Seminars on current research topics in inorganic/analytical chemistry  presented by faculty, visiting scholars, and postdoctoral and senior   graduate students.

CHEM 271.title: Bioinorganic Chemistry
CHEM 271.description: Selected topics in bioinorganic chemistry and metal-lobiochemistry with a  major focus on recent developments. Topics will include discussions of   metalloproteins and corresponding model compound investigations. Emphasis  will be on reaction mechanisms and spectroscopic properties of metal sites.

CHEM 271A.title: Synthesis and Properties of Macromolecules
CHEM 271A.description: Basics of preparation of polymer and macromolecular assemblies, and characterization of large molecules and assemblies. Discussion of chemical structure, bonding, and reactivity.

CHEM 272.title: Reaction Mechanisms in Organometallic and Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 272.description: Discussion of chemical reaction mechanisms. Emphasis will be on fundamental reactions of metal compounds such as substitution, addition, elimination, and redox reactions for homogenous catalysis mechanisms and other complex systems.

CHEM 273.title: Structural Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 273.description: The use of x-ray and neutron scattering to characterize solid state  materials. Subjects include the crystal unit cell, space groups,   structure determination and refinement. It is recommended that the   student have an elementary introduction to vectors, matrices and   fourier series.

CHEM 274.title: Solid State Inorganic/Materials
CHEM 274.description: An introductory course describing the synthesis, physical      characterization, structure, electronic properties and uses of solid state materials.

CHEM 275.title: Physical-Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 275.description: Bonding theory, thermodynamics, and structure of inorganic compounds. Applications of physical techniques to the study of inorganic (and organometallic) reactions and their mechanisms.

CHEM 276.title: Photochemical and Photophysical Properties of Inorganic and Organometallic Compounds and Materials
CHEM 276.description: Discussion of the mechanics of fundamental physical and chemical events  which follow absorption of light by inorganic or organometallic    chromophores. Consideration of homogeneous and heterogeneous systems as  well as the design and operation of photo-optical and photoelectrical  devices.

CHEM 277.title: Introduction to Inorganic Materials
CHEM 277.description: Structures of inorganic materials: close-packing, linking of simple  polyhedra. Factors that control structure: ionic radii, covalency,   ligand field effects, metal-metal bonding, electron/ atom ratios.  Structure-property relationships in e.g. spinels, garnets,     perovskites, rutiles, flourites, zeolites, b-  aluminas, graphites,  common inorganic glasses.

CHEM 279.title: Selected Topics in Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 279.comments: Course may be repeated with a different topic (18 units maximum).
CHEM 279.description: This course is designed to reflect recent developments in inorganic chemistry.

CHEM 281.title: Protein Crystallography
CHEM 281.description: Introduction to diffraction techniques. protein crystal growth and   morphology. Data collection and reduction strategies. Approaches for   solving the phase problem. Crystallographic refinement, including    molecular dynamics. Interpretation of crystal structures.

CHEM 282A.title: Synthesis and Bonding of Small Conjugated Molecules
CHEM 282A.description: Examination of small organic molecules used in optoelectronic devices:   film transistors; light emitting diodes and solar cells.  Methods for  their synthesis. Influence of molecular structure on energies of molecular orbitals.  Development of structure/function relationships based on solid  state arrangements.

CHEM 282B.title: Organic Semiconductors for Energy Conversion
CHEM 282B.description: Basic photophysics of organic semiconductors.  Examination of energy level alignments and solid state arrangements required for the conversion of   solar energy into useful electrical energy.  Important device      considerations for evaluating power conversion efficiencies.  Comparison of different solar conversion technologies.

CHEM 284.title: Chemical Literature
CHEM 284.comments: Does not count toward core academic units for the Chemistry PhD program.
CHEM 284.description: Lectures and exercises on the literature and other information resources of use in chemistry.

CHEM 285.title: Synthetic Chemistry of Macromolecules
CHEM 285.description: Molecular architecture and classifica tion of macromolecules. Different  methods for the preparation of polymers: free radical polymerization,  ionicpolymerization, condensation polymerization and coordination    polymerization. bulk, solution, and emulsion polymerization. Principles of copolymerization, blockcopolymerization, grafting, network formation,  chemical reactions on polymers.

CHEM 286.title: Organometallic Chemistry: Structure, Bonding, and Applications
CHEM 286.description: Synthesis, structure, and reactivity of organometallic complexes, with an emphasis on bonding and electronic structure. Homogeneous catalysis and small molecule activation, especially in the context of the energy conversion and storage, will also be discussed. Graduate students will be required to demonstrate a deeper understanding of the course material during class discussions and in submitted work.  Graduate students will additionally be graded separately on all course work, including exams.

CHEM 290.title: Seminar in Chemistry and Biochemistry
CHEM 290.description: Presentation of seminar required of all departmental graduate students.

CHEM 293.title: Faculty Research Seminar
CHEM 293.description: A series of seminars by departmental faculty describ ing their active  research projects.

CHEM 501A.title: Techniques of Teaching and Laboratory Class Supervision
CHEM 501A.description: An initial two-three day workshop is followed by weekly discussion. Topics covered: laboratory organization, supervising experiments, safety, presentations, leading discussions, writing quizzes, advising, and grading. Aimed at new teaching assistants.

CHEM 501B.title: Techniques of Teaching and Laboratory Class Supervision
CHEM 501B.description: An initial two-three day workshop is followed by weekly discussion. Topics covered: laboratory organization, supervising experiments, safety, presentations, leading discussions, writing quizzes, advising, and grading. Aimed at new teaching assistants.

CHEM 501C.title: Techniques of Teaching and Laboratory Class Supervision
CHEM 501C.description: An initial two-three day workshop is followed by weekly discussion. Topics covered: laboratory organization, supervising experiments, safety, presentations, leading discussions, writing quizzes, advising, and grading. Aimed at new teaching assistants.

CHEM 502A.title: Organic Chemistry Techniques of Teaching and Laboratory Class Supervision
CHEM 502A.description: An initial two-three day workshop is followed by weekly discussion. Topics covered: laboratory organization, supervising experiments, safety,   presentations, leading discussions, writing quizzes, advising, and   grading. Aimed at new teaching assistants in Organic Chemistry.

CHEM 502B.title: Organic Chemistry Techniques of Teaching and Laboratory Class Supervision
CHEM 502B.description: An initial two-three day workshop is followed by weekly discussion. Topics covered: laboratory organization, supervising experiments, safety,   presentations, leading discussions, writing quizzes, advising, and   grading. Aimed at new teaching assistants in Organic Chemistry.

CHEM 502C.title: Organic Chemistry Techniques of Teaching and Laboratory Class Supervision
CHEM 502C.description: An initial two-three day workshop is followed by weekly discussion. Topics covered: laboratory organization, supervising experiments, safety,   presentations, leading discussions, writing quizzes, advising, and   grading. Aimed at new teaching assistants in Organic Chemistry.

CHEM 595.title: Group Studies
CHEM 595.description: Critical review of research in selected fields. Regular meetings are held  in which the student presents for discussion information from the recent chemical literature.

CHEM 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
CHEM 596.comments: No more than half the units necessary for the master's degree may be taken in Chemistry 596. Same course as BMB 596.
CHEM 596.description: Individual tutorial. Instructor is usually the student's major research  advisor. Each faculty member has a unique number designation.

CHEM 597.comments: No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree(s).
CHEM 597.description: Instructor should be the student's major professor or chairman of the  doctoral committee.

CHEM 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
CHEM 598.comments: No unit credit will be given.
CHEM 598.description: Only for research underlying the thesis, writing the thesis. Instructor  should be the chairman of the student's thesis committee.

CHEM 599.title: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation
CHEM 599.description: Only for research underlying the dissertation, writing the dissertation. Instructor should be the chair of the student's doctoral committee.
